questions.content:
What are the limitations to taxi with deflated or damaged tires ?

1- If a maximum of one tire per gear is deflated (consider 3 gears), maximum taxi speed is 7 kt.

2- If a maximum of two tires are deflated on the same main gear (and maximum one main gear is concerned), maximum taxi speed is 3 kt.

3- Nose wheel steering angle is limited to 30 degrees.

4- Low speed taxi can only be performed if tires are deflated, not damaged.

5- Low speed taxi speed can be performed with deflated or damaged tires.
questions.explanation:
FCOM-LIM-LG-Taxi with deflated or damaged tires

There are a lot of useful information in FCTM-PR-AEP-LG-Taxi with Deflated or Damaged Tires

First, the crew must identify and ensure that the number and position of deflated tires are in accordance with the limitations. The tire pressure indication on the Wheel SD page is great tool to help identifying deflated/damaged tires.

If tires are damaged or out of tolerance, tires must be changed before taxing.

Also remember that if damage is suspected, the flight crew must apply the "Wheel tire damage suspected" procedure from the QRH (QRH-ABN-28).

questions.content: When is ice accretion considers as severe?
questions.explanation:
FCOM-LIM-ICE RAIN-Definition of Severe Ice Accretion

Ice accretion is considered severe when the ice accumulation on the airframe reaches a thickness of approximately 5 mm (0.2 in) or more.

questions.content: How long in advance can you make a proeficiency check for a revalidation of a class or type rating?
questions.explanation:
As per EASA Easy Access Rules for Aircrew (Regulation (EU) No 1178/2011) - FCL.740.A

You can pass your proeficiency check within the 3 months immediately preceding the expiry date of the rating.

questions.content: What is the maximum speed during landing gear retraction? (VLO)
questions.explanation:
AFM-LIM-SPD-VLO and VLE/MLE

Safety First n°24

"VLO /MLO is the maximum speed/Mach to operate (both extend and retract) the landing gear.VLO /MLO is not displayed on the PFD; it is available on the speeds placard in the cockpit"

answers.content: The certified maximum crosswind limit is greater than 30 kt.
There is no certification for maximum crosswind.

questions.content: What is the maximum demonstrated or certified crosswind for takeoff/landing on a dry runway (Gusts Included)?
questions.explanation:
There is no certification for maximum crosswind, only a maximum demonstrated value and it is greater than 30 knots. Exact values are as specified in FCOM-LIM-AG-OPS-Airport Operations and Wind Limitations and should be 38 kt for A319/320 and 35 kt for A320 NEO.

However, please refer to your airline documentation to know the maximum crosswind component allowed in your situation for landing.

questions.content: Green dot speed is the minimum drag speed.
questions.explanation:
FCOM-DSC-22_10-50-20-Characterstics Speeds

More Information in Safety First n°21

This statement is false as Green Dot speed is the best lift-to-drag ratio speed. It is also the engine-out operating speed in clean configuration.

Green dot speed can be computed as follow:

- Below 20.000ft, GD = 2 x weight (in tons) + 80

- Above 20.000ft, GD = 2 x weight (in tons) + 80 + 1 kt per 1000ft

questions.content: Open configuration, close configuration are 2 of how many avionic ventilation configurations possible?
questions.explanation:
FCOM-DSC-21-30-20

The different modes are: open circuit configuration, closed circuit configuration, intermediate configuration, abnormal configuration and smoke configuration (5 configurations).

 

Open Configuration (on ground only)

In open configuration, when the skin of the aircraft is warm enough* , the air from outside is filtered, sent to the avionic and released outside.

air outside>avionic>outside

In some cases note that the opening of the skin air inlet valve  can be delayed to avoid condensation phenomenon.

*above 9°C or 12°C (depending on whether the skin temperature is increasing or decreasing)

Closed Configuration (on ground or inflight)

(on ground)

When the skin of the aircraft is cold*, the skin air inlet and outlet valve remain closed and air is recirculated inside the system. As the skin of the aircraft is cold, the skin heat exchanger is used to cool down the warm air coming from the avionics before being sent back to the avionic.

air inside>heat exchanger>avionic>heat exchanger>avionic>...

*(below 9°C or 12°C depending on whether the skin temperature is increasing or decreasing)

(inflight)

In flight, the system operates in closed configuration when the aircraft skin temperature is below 35°C (or 32°C depending on whether the skin temperature is increasing or decreasing).

air inside>heat exchanger>avionic>heat exchanger>avionic>...

 

Intermediate configuration (inflight only)

In flight, when the aircraft skin temperature is above 35°C (or 32°C depending on whether the skin temperature is increasing or decreasing), the configuration is similar to the closed configuration except that the skin air outlet valve is partially closed allowing some air to escape outside.

 

Abnormal configuration

When the blower or extract is in override mode, the system goes to a closed configuration except that some air is added via the air conditioning system.

In addition, if the blower fan pushbutton is set to override, the blower fan stops but the extract fan will always run regardless of any pushbutton position.

 

Smoke configuration

When smoke is detected in the avionic ventilation, blower and extract pushbuttons will be set to override. The blower fan will stop and the air conditioning will supply the cooling air which is then exhausted overbord (via the extract fan running).

air from air conditionning>avionic>outside

questions.content: Which figure of merit triggers the rejection of the GPS position by the FMS ?
questions.explanation:
FCOM-DSC--22_20-20-20-General

If the figure of merit is above 0.28nm, the FMS will reject the GPS position.

questions.content: During a RNAV approach, where can you expect the aircraft to start the final descent?
questions.explanation:
FCOM-DSC-22_30-80-30-20-Engagement Conditions

You can expect to start the final descent at the FDP (Final Descent Point) also called VIP (Vertical Intersection Point) materialized by a blue arrow (the Continue Descent symbol).

This blue arrow appears when all conditions are met. If at least one conditions is not fulfilled, the arrow will be displayed in white.

The conditions to get FINAL APP and the blue arrow are the following:

• NAV or APP NAV is engaged,
• FINAL is armed (by pressing APPR on the FCU),
• Predictions are available in FMS,
• APPROACH phase is active, and the deceleration point is sequenced,
• The aircraft is within the capture area of the FMS profile:
   ‐ Laterally: ±1.5 NM from the Final Descent Point.
   ‐ Vertically: +150 ft above the Final Descent Point.
• The aircraft intercepts a descending leg of the vertical flight path.

questions.content: Which quantity of fuel remaining in the wing inner tanks will trigger the transfer of fuel from the outer tanks to the inner tanks?
questions.explanation:
FCOM-DSC-28-10-30-Fuel Feed Sequence

The intertank transfer valves automatically open when the wing inner tanks reach 750kg.

Note: This question is not applicable to A321 has the wing fuel tank design is different.
